articles.headline: Former Memphis Officer Pleads Guilty to Federal Charges in Tyre Nichols’s Death
articles.snippet: The ex-officer pleaded guilty to two felony counts, becoming the first to admit culpability in the fatal beating of Mr. Nichols. As part of a plea deal, he is also expected to cooperate with a state murder prosecution.
articles.abstract: The ex-officer pleaded guilty to two felony counts, becoming the first to admit culpability in the fatal beating of Mr. Nichols. As part of a plea deal, he is also expected to cooperate with a state murder prosecution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Desmond Mills Jr., one of five former Memphis police officers charged in connection with the brutal beating and death of Tyre Nichols, pleaded guilty in federal court on Thursday to two felony charges of obstruction of justice and excessive force.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Jessica Jaglois

articles.headline: Are Higher Rates Slowing the Economy? A Zoo Offers Clues.
articles.snippet: Economists are surprised by how strong the economy remains with rates at a 22-year high. But there are some signs of slowing, if you know where to look.
articles.abstract: Economists are surprised by how strong the economy remains with rates at a 22-year high. But there are some signs of slowing, if you know where to look.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leesburg Animal Park in Northern Virginia has seen strong business at its Pumpkin Village festival this autumn. Even with rainy weekends and a jump in admission prices, families have been coming out to visit the petting zoo, ride on giant slides and zigzag through a hay-bale maze.

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Encircle Gaza City as Global Criticism of Strikes Mounts
articles.snippet: An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli soldiers had surrounded Gaza’s largest city. White House officials said they would urge Israel to “pause” its bombardment on humanitarian grounds.
articles.abstract: An Israeli military spokesman said that Israeli soldiers had surrounded Gaza’s largest city. White House officials said they would urge Israel to “pause” its bombardment on humanitarian grounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Israeli military announced that ground troops had encircled Gaza City on Thursday, criticism mounted of the death toll inflicted by Israeli airstrikes, with one United Nations agency suggesting the bombing campaign could be a war crime.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Is Found Guilty of 7 Counts of Fraud and Conspiracy
articles.snippet: The case against the founder of the failed FTX exchange had come to symbolize the excesses of the volatile cryptocurrency industry.
articles.abstract: The case against the founder of the failed FTX exchange had come to symbolize the excesses of the volatile cryptocurrency industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the tousle-haired mogul who founded the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was convicted on Thursday of seven charges of fraud and conspiracy after a monthlong trial that laid bare the rampant hubris and risk-taking across the crypto industry.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Wild Rise and Abrupt Crash
articles.snippet: The crypto king gambled that his trading platform would make him a benevolent trillionaire. But after a fraud conviction, all bets are off.
articles.abstract: The crypto king gambled that his trading platform would make him a benevolent trillionaire. But after a fraud conviction, all bets are off.
articles.lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in the development of a new technology when the hype is so common it passes for common sense. Lawyers, accountants and regulators are nowhere to be found. Investors insist entrepreneurs take their money. The world trembles on the brink of change.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Shrugs Off Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
articles.snippet: Tech investors lauded Mr. Bankman-Fried and helped fund his FTX crypto exchange. The tech industry has since done what it does best: move on.
articles.abstract: Tech investors lauded Mr. Bankman-Fried and helped fund his FTX crypto exchange. The tech industry has since done what it does best: move on.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the four weeks that Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was on trial on fraud charges, the tech industry:

articles.headline: Somewhat Guiltily, Ukrainians Miss Matthew Perry
articles.snippet: Even as the war’s devastation rages on, Ukrainians have found space to mourn an actor who brought them comfort and laughter.
articles.abstract: Even as the war’s devastation rages on, Ukrainians have found space to mourn an actor who brought them comfort and laughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the middle of the night in Ukraine, and Natalia Sosnytska couldn’t sleep. So she opened the Instagram app on her phone — and saw that the actor Matthew Perry had died.

articles.headline: Can Humanities Survive the Budget Cuts?
articles.snippet: After years of hand-wringing about their future, liberal arts departments now face the chopping block. At risk: French, German, American studies and women’s studies.
articles.abstract: After years of hand-wringing about their future, liberal arts departments now face the chopping block. At risk: French, German, American studies and women’s studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The state auditor of Mississippi recently released an eight-page report suggesting that the state should invest more in college degree programs that could “improve the value they provide to both taxpayers and graduates.”

articles.headline: Job Growth Slows, Sowing a Mix of Concern and Calm
articles.snippet: U.S. employers added 150,000 workers in October, falling short of expectations, but the labor market retains spark nearly three years into a recovery.
articles.abstract: U.S. employers added 150,000 workers in October, falling short of expectations, but the labor market retains spark nearly three years into a recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The labor market has been relentlessly hot since the U.S. economy began to recover from the shock of the pandemic. But there are signs of cooling as the holidays approach.

articles.headline: Electric Planes, Once a Fantasy, Start to Take to the Skies
articles.snippet: How a small plane’s 16-day trip from Vermont to Florida might foreshadow a new era of battery-powered air travel long considered implausible.
articles.abstract: How a small plane’s 16-day trip from Vermont to Florida might foreshadow a new era of battery-powered air travel long considered implausible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Caputo stood on the tarmac at Burlington International Airport in Vermont in early October and looked to the clouds in the distance. He had piloted military and commercial aircraft over a long career, racking up thousands of flight hours, but the trip he was about to take would be very different.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Tony Cenicola

articles.headline: N.F.L., on Lookout for Growth, Finds Open Arms in Germany
articles.snippet: Football was introduced to the country by U.S. soldiers after World War II, but interests soared when the N.F.L. played its first regular-season game there last year.
articles.abstract: Football was introduced to the country by U.S. soldiers after World War II, but interests soared when the N.F.L. played its first regular-season game there last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 60 hardcore fans of the National Football League piled into the party space at Der Player, a fancy eatery, on a chilly evening in Hamburg, Germany, last month. Wearing jerseys and hoodies of teams like the Chicago Bears, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Las Vegas Raiders, they grabbed seats to watch a taping of “Prime Time Football Live,” which attracts thousands of viewers on YouTube.

articles.headline: As Gaza War Enters New Phase, Israel Faces Pressure Over Civilian Deaths
articles.snippet: Fears are rising that the conflict could spread to the occupied West Bank, where tensions are soaring among Palestinians angered over deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.
articles.abstract: Fears are rising that the conflict could spread to the occupied West Bank, where tensions are soaring among Palestinians angered over deadly Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a week after Israeli tanks and troops poured into Gaza, Israeli military officials say they have made steady gains against Hamas. But the ground operation, which now encircles Gaza City, is entering an acutely perilous phase, with Israeli troops advancing in an urban landscape that is honeycombed with tunnels and home to many Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: G.M.’s Cruise Moved Fast in the Driverless Race. It Got Ugly.
articles.snippet: Cruise has hired a law firm to investigate how it responded to regulators, as its cars sit idle and questions grow about its C.E.O.’s expansion plans.
articles.abstract: Cruise has hired a law firm to investigate how it responded to regulators, as its cars sit idle and questions grow about its C.E.O.’s expansion plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Kyle Vogt, the chief executive of Cruise, choked up as he recounted how a driver had killed a 4-year-old girl in a stroller at a San Francisco intersection. “It barely made the news,” he said, pausing to collect himself. “Sorry. I get emotional.”
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Cade Metz and Yiwen Lu
